The way he connected psychology with AI-driven marketing really made me think about how much of my buying is subconscious. It‚Äôs a little unsettling but also fascinating.
I love how he emphasized ethics because AI without responsibility could easily manipulate people instead of empowering them. That‚Äôs the part we often overlook in tech discussions.
His breakdown of social proof and scarcity was spot-on. It really shows how AI is just amplifying tactics that already work on us.
The storytelling aspect stood out to me, it feels so timeless, yet now AI can replicate it at scale. Makes me wonder if we‚Äôll even notice when a machine is pulling at our emotions.
Thanks for your insights , yes more on the psychology !
True ‚Äî AI can move us with stories, but the real magic still lies in the human intention behind them.
The talk makes me question how much of my loyalty to brands is actually real versus engineered. That‚Äôs kind of a scary realization.
I liked how he framed AI as transformative but also a double-edged sword. It all comes down to who‚Äôs controlling the narrative behind the algorithms.
Scarcity being used by AI feels dangerous, because machines don‚Äôt have a sense of balance. They‚Äôll just keep pushing until people are exhausted.
The part about consistency in messaging resonated with me. It‚Äôs amazing how predictable we humans can be once AI maps our behavior.
Yes indeed!
I appreciate that he didn‚Äôt demonize AI but instead highlighted the responsibility of marketers. That perspective felt more balanced than the usual doom-and-gloom talks.
The psychology he explained almost makes me want to audit my own buying decisions. How many of my ‚Äúchoices‚Äù were really mine?
His mention of sustainability alongside AI was refreshing. It‚Äôs rare to hear marketing experts put both in the same sentence.
What struck me most is how emotions are the universal language, even in a digital world. AI just happens to be fluent in exploiting it.
The reminder about ethics is so important, because without it, AI marketing could become manipulation disguised as personalization. That‚Äôs a thin line.
I couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about the consistency principle AI makes it so easy to reinforce habits we don‚Äôt even notice forming. That‚Äôs both powerful and risky.
Storytelling being central to AI marketing is wild. Machines are now the ones spinning the tales we use to define ourselves.

This made me rethink the ads I scroll past every day. They‚Äôre not just random‚Äîthey‚Äôre designed to hit my psychological triggers.
The emphasis on emotional connections reminded me that at the end of the day, marketing is about people, not products. AI just adds another layer of sophistication to that.
I admire how he didn‚Äôt shy away from the darker side of AI marketing. It‚Äôs refreshing to hear an expert acknowledge both sides of the coin.
His experience really came through when he tied psychology to technology so seamlessly. It felt less like theory and more like wisdom from the field.
The talk made me reflect on trust do we trust the technology itself, or the people programming it? That‚Äôs probably the real question.

It‚Äôs refreshing to hear someone with experience in marketing talk about values, not just data. That‚Äôs what gives this talk weight.
He reminded me that technology is neutral‚Äîit‚Äôs our intent that decides if it helps or harms. That‚Äôs especially true with AI marketing.
His experience across CRM and digital tools makes the warnings real. He‚Äôs not anti-tech, he‚Äôs pro-ethical tech.
